questions.text: An elderly patient complains of multiple clots in his urine. Which catheter should be used in this patient which can facilitate irrigation and clot removal from the urinary bladder? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 22 French Foley's 3 lumen catheter

 

Explanation: 


A triple lumen catheter is ideal for managing clots in bladder as it has:

 

  • First channel for urine drainage
  • Second channel for balloon inflation
  • Third channel specifically for continuous irrigation
  • 22 French size is appropriate for adequate drainage of clots
  • Commonly used after procedures like TURP where post-operative clots are expected
  • Allows simultaneous irrigation and drainage

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 22 French Foley's 4 lumen catheter - Incorrect

 

  • Does not exist in clinical practice
  • No requirement for fourth lumen

 

Option C. 22 French Foley's 2 lumen catheter - Incorrect

 

  • Has only drainage and balloon inflation channels
  • No separate channel for irrigation
  • Cannot perform continuous irrigation effectively

 

Option D. 22 French Foley's 1 lumen catheter - Incorrect

 

  • Cannot be self-retaining as no balloon inflation channel
  • No irrigation capability
  • Inadequate for managing clots
  • Not practical for this clinical scenario

 

Educational Objective: 


A three-way Foley's catheter (22Fr) is the appropriate choice for managing bladder clots as it allows simultaneous drainage and irrigation through separate channels.

questions.text: Which patient category is classified as "green" according to the triage system? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ambulatory patients

 

  • The triage system is a method used by medical professionals to prioritize patient care based on the severity of their condition.
  • The triage system typically uses a color-coding scheme to classify patients into different categories.
  • These categories help in quickly identifying which patients need immediate attention and which can wait.
  • Green category: Patients classified under the "green" category are those with non-urgent medical needs. These patients are ambulatory, meaning they can walk and move around on their own. Their injuries or illnesses are minor and do not require immediate medical intervention. These patients can safely wait for medical attention without any significant risk to their health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medium risk patients: Patients classified as medium risk typically fall under the "yellow" category in the triage system. These patients have urgent medical needs but their condition is not immediately life-threatening. They need medical attention soon but can wait for a short period without significant risk to their health.

 

Option C. High risk patients: High risk patients are usually classified under the "red" category. These patients need immediate life-saving interventions due to critical conditions such as severe bleeding, difficulty breathing, or major trauma. Delaying treatment for these patients could result in severe complications or death.

 

Option D. Dead patients: Patients classified as dead or who have injuries that are beyond medical intervention fall under the "black" category. These patients are either deceased or have injuries that are so severe that survival is not expected even with medical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "green" category in the triage system is used for ambulatory patients with minor injuries or illnesses.
  • These patients do not require immediate medical attention and can safely wait for treatment.

questions.text: Three Testicle appearance’ is seen in? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spermatocele

 

The 'Three Testicle appearance' refers to the presence of a third mass in addition to the normal testicles, often seen in cases of spermatocele.

 

  • Spermatocele:
    • Description: A unilocular retention cyst located in the head of the epididymis behind the upper pole of the testis.
    • Contents: Contains spermatozoa and typically has a 'barley water' appearance.
    • Appearance: Creates an additional palpable mass in the scrotum, which can be interpreted as a 'third testicle.'
    • Treatment: Management involves either aspiration or surgical excision if the cyst is large or symptomatic.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Vaginal hydrocele:
    • This is an accumulation of serous fluid between the layers of the tunica vaginalis surrounding the testicle. It does not create a distinct 'third testicle' mass but rather causes a generalized swelling of the scrotum.
  • Option C. Epididymo-orchitis:
    • This is an inflammation of the epididymis and/or the testicle, usually due to infection. It typically presents with pain, swelling, and tenderness, rather than a distinct third mass.
  • Option D. Torsion Testis:
    • Testicular torsion involves the twisting of the spermatic cord, cutting off blood supply to the testis. This is a surgical emergency presenting with sudden, severe pain and swelling of the testis, but not with an additional palpable mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 'Three Testicle appearance' is characteristic of a spermatocele, which is a retention cyst located in the head of the epididymis, creating an additional palpable mass in the scrotum.

questions.text: A morbidly obese patient underwent cholecystectomy and subsequently complained of pain in the legs after walking for some distance. Which investigation would be most appropriate for further evaluation? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duplex scan 

 

The patient's symptoms suggest occurrence of post operative Deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The investigations listed are used to evaluate vascular conditions:

 

This ultrasound-based diagnostic technique combines traditional ultrasound to visualize the structure of the blood vessels and Doppler ultrasound to visualize blood flow within the vessels. It is the first-line investigation for DVT as it is non-invasive, widely available, and cost-effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI angiography: Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is a type of MRI that visualizes blood vessels. It is a good non-invasive option to visualize blood flow and vascular anatomy but is less commonly used as a first-line test due to cost and availability.

 

Option C. CT angiography: This imaging modality uses computed tomography (CT) combined with a contrast agent to visualize vascular structures. It's useful in detailed mapping of blood vessels but exposes the patient to radiation and contrast, which may not be suitable for all patients.

 

Option D. USG: Ultrasound (USG) is useful for various diagnostic purposes but on its own may not be sufficient for a full vascular assessment in the case of DVT unless it's part of a duplex scan.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For a morbidly obese patient presenting with leg pain consistent with DVT post-cholecystectomy, a duplex scan is the most appropriate initial investigation to evaluate for DVT.

choices.text: It is done as a life-saving measure
It is done so as to enable the patient to use adequate prosthesis for walking
It is done for emotional care and support
It is done for good functionality

questions.text: A person fell from the train and injured his both legs a few years back. The amputation was done as shown in the image. What is the most likely reason for doing such an amputation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is done as a life-saving measure

 

In cases of severe traumatic injury, such as a person falling from a train and suffering significant leg injuries, amputation is often performed as a life-saving measure. When a limb is crushed, it can lead to a crush syndrome, where the release of myoglobin and potassium from the damaged muscles into the bloodstream can cause acute tubular necrosis of the kidneys and hyperkalemia, leading to fatal arrhythmias. To prevent these life-threatening complications, immediate amputation of the crushed limb is necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is done so as to enable the patient to use adequate prosthesis for walking: While amputations are sometimes performed with prosthetic use in mind, this is not the primary consideration in emergency situations involving severe trauma.

 

Option C. It is done for emotional care and support: Amputation is not performed for emotional care; it is a surgical intervention aimed at addressing severe physical injuries.

 

Option D. It is done for good functionality: Functionality considerations, such as optimizing the stump for prosthetic fitting, are secondary to the immediate need to save the patient’s life in cases of severe trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of severe limb trauma, such as a crush injury, amputation is primarily performed as a life-saving measure to prevent complications like crush syndrome and its associated risks.

questions.text: A patient has undergone cholecystectomy few days back and now the patient has presented with upper Abdominal pain. MRCP was done which showed leak of bile from the cystic duct stump. Pt is hemodynamically stable which of the following should be the next line of management? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ERCP and stenting

 

The correct option is Option B. ERCP (Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography) and stenting

 

ERCP is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used primarily to diagnose and treat conditions of the bile and pancreatic ducts. In the context of a known bile leak, as revealed by the MRCP, ERCP can be employed both to visualize the site of the leak and to deploy a stent. This stent can bridge the gap where the leak is, allowing the bile to flow normally into the intestine and simultaneously giving the leaky site a chance to heal. This makes it a less invasive option than surgical intervention for managing bile leaks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): This is a diagnostic imaging tool. A CECT provides detailed imaging of internal structures and can help in diagnosing a variety of conditions. However, in the context of the given scenario where the patient has had an MRCP that already shows a bile leak, a further CECT might not provide additional useful information for direct management.

 

Option C. Exploratory laparotomy: While it can be used to directly visualize and repair a bile leak, it's a major surgical procedure with potential complications. It's generally considered when other less invasive options are not viable or have failed.

 

Option D. Conservative treatment with antibiotics: While antibiotics can help to prevent or treat infections, they won't directly address a bile leak. Hence, relying solely on antibiotics wouldn't solve the main problem. However, antibiotics might be used in conjunction with other treatments if there's a concern about bile-related infection or sepsis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a hemodynamically stable patient with a bile leak post-cholecystectomy, as shown by MRCP, the next line of management is ERCP and stenting to bridge the leak and allow healing.

choices.text: Ileostomy and definitive surgery later
Ileal pouch-anal anastomosis
Resection of the diseased segment and anastomosis of the normal segment
Right hemicolectomy and ileo - transverse anastomosis

questions.text: A patient suffering from inflammatory bowel disease presented with ileal perforation and peritonitis. Intra-operatively, severe peritoneal contamination is found. What is the surgical management of choice in this patient? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ileostomy and definite surgery later

 

This patient has Crohn’s disease, which can present with terminal ileitis and complications like perforation peritonitis. The appropriate surgical management depends on the extent of peritoneal contamination:

 

  • Severe Peritoneal Contamination: If there is severe peritoneal contamination due to the perforation, performing an ileostomy is the preferred approach. This diverts the fecal stream and allows the inflammation and infection to subside before a definitive surgery is performed later (typically after 4-6 weeks). This approach minimizes the risk of complications from primary anastomosis in a contaminated field.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA):
    • This surgical procedure is more commonly used for patients with ulcerative colitis, not Crohn's disease. It's not appropriate in the context of an acute perforation and peritonitis due to Crohn’s disease.
  • Option C. Resection of the diseased segment and anastomosis of the normal segment:
    • While this might be an appropriate approach for isolated disease without complications, it's less commonly chosen in the setting of acute perforation with severe contamination. The risk is that the newly created anastomosis might not heal properly, leading to another leak and peritonitis.
  • Option D. Right hemicolectomy and ileo-transverse anastomosis:
    • This involves removing the right side of the colon and part of the small intestine. It's an extensive surgery and would be more applicable if there were a malignancy or a stricture in the right colon. In the setting of an acute perforation and contamination from Crohn's disease, this might be considered too aggressive, where a more limited resection and diversion should be done.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with Crohn’s disease presenting with ileal perforation and severe peritoneal contamination, the preferred surgical management is to perform an ileostomy and plan for definitive surgery later, to minimize complications and allow for stabilization of the patient.

questions.text: A case of urinary bladder stone with a history of Proteus infection is likely to be? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phosphate

 

Proteus infection in the urinary tract is commonly associated with the formation of struvite stones, which are also known as triple phosphate stones. Struvite stones consist of magnesium, ammonium, and phosphate. Proteus species produce the enzyme urease, which hydrolyzes urea into ammonia, increasing the urine pH and promoting the precipitation of phosphate, magnesium, and ammonium to form struvite stones.

 

These stones are often described as "infection stones" because they typically form in alkaline urine in the presence of a urinary tract infection caused by urease-producing bacteria like Proteus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxalate: Oxalate stones are primarily composed of calcium oxalate and are not directly related to infections. They are often associated with dietary factors, hyperoxaluria, or conditions causing increased oxalate excretion.

 

Option C. Uric acid: Uric acid stones form in acidic urine and are related to conditions that increase uric acid levels, such as gout or a high purine diet. They are not associated with Proteus infections or other urease-producing bacteria.

 

Option D. Cystine: Cystine stones are associated with cystinuria, a genetic disorder that leads to the excessive excretion of cystine in the urine. These stones are characterized by their hexagonal crystal shape but are not related to Proteus infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urinary bladder stones associated with Proteus infection are most likely to be struvite (triple phosphate) stones, formed due to the alkalinizing effect of urease-producing bacteria on the urine.

choices.text: The extent does not cross the wound margins
Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence
Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity
A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

questions.text: A patient visits the clinic and presents with a raised and firm scar on their chest, which is larger than the original wound. The physician suspects a keloid scar and begins to explain the diagnosis and potential treatment options. Which of the following statements are true with regards to a keloid scar?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

 

A keloid scar forms due to an increase in the level of growth factors: This statement is true. Keloid scars are thought to develop due to an overproduction of growth factors, such as transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta), which stimulate the production of collagen and other extracellular matrix components. This abnormal healing response results in the excessive growth of scar tissue beyond the original wound margin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The extent does not cross the wound margins: This statement is not true. Keloid scars are characterized by an excessive growth of fibrous tissue beyond the original wound margin. They tend to be larger, more raised, and thicker than the original wound.

 

Option B. Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence: This statement is also not entirely true. While surgical removal of keloid scars can be effective, the risk of recurrence is high, and the scar may actually grow larger than the original one.

 

Option C. Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity: This statement is not true. Keloid scars are characterized by an overproduction of collagen, which leads to the thick and raised appearance of the scar. There may also be increased vascularity within the scar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keloid scars are caused by an overproduction of growth factors like TGF-β, leading to excessive collagen formation and scar tissue that extends beyond the wound margins.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a 6-year-old male who presents with a midline neck swelling that moves upward with the protrusion of the tongue?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sistrunk operation

 

The 6-year-old male presents with a midline neck swelling that moves upward with the protrusion of the tongue, which is characteristic of a thyroglossal duct cyst. This cyst forms from remnants of the thyroglossal duct, which usually obliterates as the thyroid gland descends from the foramen cecum at the base of the tongue to its final position in the neck. When part of this duct remains patent, it can form a cyst.

 

The appropriate treatment for a thyroglossal duct cyst is the Sistrunk operation. This surgical procedure involves removing the cyst along with the central portion of the hyoid bone and a tract leading to the base of the tongue to ensure complete excision and reduce the risk of recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemithyroidectomy: This is incorrect as it involves removing one lobe of the thyroid gland, which is not necessary for treating a thyroglossal duct cyst.

 

Option C. Total thyroidectomy: This is incorrect because removing the entire thyroid gland is not indicated for a thyroglossal duct cyst.

 

Option D. Subtotal thyroidectomy: This is incorrect as it involves partial removal of the thyroid gland, which is also not indicated for a thyroglossal duct cyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sistrunk operation is the treatment of choice for a thyroglossal duct cyst, involving the removal of the cyst, the central portion of the hyoid bone, and the tract to the base of the tongue.

questions.text: During the assessment of the breathing component of a trauma patient, which of the following is the most life-threatening injury that should be identified and managed immediately? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tension pneumothorax

 

Injuries that significantly impair ventilation in the short term, such as tension pneumothorax, must be identified during the primary survey and treated immediately.

 

It is important to note that the ABCDE protocol of trauma care should be followed, with the primary survey focusing on identifying and managing life-threatening injuries, followed by the secondary survey to identify all other injuries

 

Tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and compresses the lung, causing it to collapse. This can lead to a rapid buildup of pressure in the chest cavity, compressing the heart and great vessels, which can be life-threatening. It is crucial to identify and manage tension pneumothorax promptly by performing a needle decompression to release the trapped air.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical spine injury: While cervical spine injuries can be serious and require prompt attention, they are not primarily related to the respiratory system. They can result in neurological deficits but are not immediately life-threatening in terms of breathing.

 

Option C. Blunt cardiac injury: Blunt cardiac injury can result from chest trauma and may affect the heart's function. While it can be serious, it may not immediately impact the patient's ability to breathe. However, it requires evaluation and management.

 

Option D. Flail chest: Flail chest is no longer considered an immediate threat to life as per ATLS 2018 guidelines.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters are included in qSOFA score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SBP, RR, GCS score

 

  • The Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) score is used to identify patients with suspected infection who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit.
  • The qSOFA score includes three clinical criteria:
    1. Respiratory rate (RR) ≥ 22/min: A high respiratory rate indicates respiratory distress and a higher risk of organ failure.
    2. Systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≤ 100 mmHg: Low blood pressure indicates hemodynamic instability and a higher risk of mortality.
    3. Change in mental status (GCS score): Altered mental status, measured by the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), indicates possible central nervous system dysfunction.
  • Each criterion is assigned one point, and a qSOFA score of ≥2 suggests a higher risk of adverse outcomes and increased mortality.

 

qSOFA (Quick SOFA) Criteria

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BP, RR, and CBC: This option includes blood pressure and respiratory rate, but the complete blood count (CBC) is not part of the qSOFA score.

 

Option B. Creatinine, PR, BP:  Creatinine and pulse rate (PR) are not part of the qSOFA score. Blood pressure is included, but the qSOFA score focuses on systolic blood pressure specifically.

 

Option C. RR, Body temperature, PR: Respiratory rate is part of the qSOFA score, but body temperature and pulse rate are not included.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The qSOFA score includes three clinical criteria: respiratory rate (RR) ≥ 22/min, systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≤ 100 mmHg, and altered mental status (GCS score).
  • A qSOFA score of ≥2 indicates a higher risk of poor outcomes in patients with suspected infection.

questions.text: A patient presents six months after an abdominal hysterectomy with a swelling at the scar site. Initially reducible, the swelling has now become irreducible and tender. The rest of the abdomen is normal on palpation. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bowel strangulation

 

Explanation:

 

This is a case of strangulated incisional hernia because:

 

  • History of previous surgery (hysterectomy) leading to incisional hernia
  • Initially reducible swelling suggests hernia
  • Progression to irreducibility with tenderness indicates strangulation
  • Strangulation occurs when blood supply to herniated bowel is compromised
  • Requires urgent surgical intervention to prevent bowel gangrene

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paralytic ileus: Incorrect

 

  • Presents with generalized abdominal distention, not localized swelling
  • No history of recent surgery or precipitating factors
  • Usually associated with absent bowel sounds
  • Does not present as reducible turning irreducible swelling

 

Option B. Perforation peritonitis: Incorrect

 

  • Presents with generalized abdominal pain and distention
  • Associated with severe systemic symptoms
  • Shows signs of peritonitis all over abdomen
  • Not localized to surgical scar

 

Option D. Ascites: Incorrect

 

  • Causes generalized abdominal distention
  • Fluid collects in dependent areas
  • Shows shifting dullness
  • Not localized to surgical scar

 

Educational Objective:

 

A previously reducible hernia becoming irreducible with tenderness indicates strangulation, which is a surgical emergency requiring immediate intervention.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents in surgery OPD with midline swelling in the neck. The swelling moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroglossal cyst

 

  • Pathology – Remnant of thyroglossal duct
  • Most common site – midline à Subhyoid
  • C/F – Presents in 2nd /3rd decade of life as midline neck swelling which moves up on tongue protrusion and on deglutition.
  • Treatment - Sistrunk’s operation
  • Long standing thyroglossal cyst has a risk of papillary carcinoma thyroid

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branchial cyst: Failure of obliteration of branchial cleft. Cystic swelling (soft)- typically in a teenager. Swelling at upper 1/3rd + middle 1/3rd junction of sternocleidomastoid.

 

 

Option C. Plunging ranula: Presents as Swelling in floor of mouth, Fluctuation present, Brilliant transillumination.

 

 

Option D. Dermoid cyst: Caused when skin and skin structures become trapped during fetal development.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue is characteristic of a thyroglossal cyst, which is a remnant of the thyroglossal duct.
  • The treatment is typically surgical removal via the Sistrunk procedure.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented to the emergency with upper abdominal pain radiating to the back. On X-ray, Colon Cut off sign is seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute Pancreatitis

 

Acute pancreatitis is an inflammation of the pancreas that manifests with severe upper abdominal pain that radiates to the back. The pain is often described as being relieved by sitting or bending forward. One of the radiological signs associated with acute pancreatitis seen on abdominal X-ray is the "colon cut off sign." This sign indicates a gas-filled segment of the colon at the splenic flexure, which abruptly ends due to spasm or inflammation caused by the nearby inflamed pancreas.

 

Common Causes:

 

  • Gallstones
  • Alcohol consumption

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Severe epigastric pain radiating to the back
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Elevated serum amylase and lipase levels

 

Radiological Signs on X-ray:

 

  • Sentinel loop sign: Dilated loop of small bowel near the inflamed pancreas.
  • Renal halo sign: A fat-attenuation line seen in the perirenal space.
  • Gasless abdomen: Lack of gas in the intestine due to ileus.
  • Ground glass appearance: Due to edema and inflammation.
  • Colon cut off sign: Gas-filled segment of the colon at the splenic flexure abruptly ending.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Acute Cholecystitis:
    • Acute cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder, typically presenting with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and positive Murphy's sign. Radiological findings might show gallstones and thickening of the gallbladder wall but not the colon cut off sign.
  • Option B. Acute Appendicitis:
    • Acute appendicitis typically presents with right lower quadrant pain, fever, and tenderness at McBurney's point. Imaging might show an enlarged appendix or localized fluid collection but not the colon cut off sign.
  • Option D. Chronic Pancreatitis:
    • Chronic pancreatitis involves persistent inflammation of the pancreas, leading to fibrosis. Symptoms include chronic abdominal pain, malabsorption, and diabetes mellitus. Imaging might show calcifications in the pancreas and ductal changes, but the colon cut off sign is not typically associated with chronic pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "colon cut off sign" on X-ray is indicative of acute pancreatitis, characterized by severe epigastric pain radiating to the back.

questions.text: Identify the stapler in the image given below: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Linear stapler

 

The above instrument is a linear stapler.

 

Use: It is used to close the bowel completely or partially.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A linear stapler is used to close the bowel completely or partially, providing a secure and uniform closure in gastrointestinal surgeries.

questions.text: Which of the following incisions is cosmetically preferred for appendectomy? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lanz

 

The Lanz incision is the most cosmetically preferred incision for an appendectomy. It is made along the skin crease, resulting in a less noticeable scar.

 

Gridiron or McBurney incisions are muscle-splitting incisions centered at McBurney's point. They are traditional incisions used for appendectomy but may result in more visible scars compared to the Lanz incision.

 

Rutherford Morrison incision is a muscle-cutting incision that provides adequate exposure during appendectomy, especially for more complicated cases. However, it is less cosmetically appealing due to the larger scar it leaves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gridiron: This incision is centered at McBurney's point and involves splitting the muscles, which can leave a more noticeable scar.

 

Option B. Rutherford Morrison: This is a muscle-cutting incision that provides good exposure for appendectomy but results in a larger, less cosmetic scar.

 

Option D. McBurney: Similar to the Gridiron incision, it is centered at McBurney's point and involves splitting the muscles, leading to a more visible scar compared to the Lanz incision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lanz incision is cosmetically preferred for appendectomy due to its alignment along the skin crease, resulting in a less noticeable scar compared to other traditional incisions.

choices.text: Needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space
Tube thoracostomy in the 4th intercostal space

questions.text: Adult male, following a road traffic accident, was brought to the emergency with respiratory distress. On clinical evaluation, breath sounds were absent on one side and subcutaneous emphysema was noted. Vitals were unstable. Chest X-ray showed the following. Next step in the management of this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space

 

The patient presents with signs and symptoms indicative of a tension pneumothorax, a medical emergency. Tension pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased pressure on the affected side, which compresses the lung and shifts the mediastinum to the opposite side.

 

Key signs of tension pneumothorax include:

 

  • Respiratory distress
  • Absent breath sounds on one side
  • Subcutaneous emphysema
  • Unstable vitals
  • Mediastinal shift visible on the chest X-ray

 

Immediate Management: The first step in managing a tension pneumothorax is needle decompression to quickly relieve the pressure. This procedure is typically performed in the 2nd intercostal space at the midclavicular line, not the 5th intercostal space as mentioned in the answer. However, for the context of the given options, we will proceed with needle decompression as the primary action.

 

Subsequent Management: Following needle decompression, Intercostal Drain (ICD) should be performed to ensure continued evacuation of air and prevent recurrence. This is usually done in the "triangle of safety." This the best management in this type of condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tube thoracostomy in the 4th intercostal space: While a tube thoracostomy is a necessary step following initial needle decompression, it is not the immediate next step in the acute management of tension pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Endotracheal intubation: This procedure is indicated if there is a direct airway injury or if the patient is unable to maintain their airway. In the case of tension pneumothorax, the primary issue is with ventilation, not the airway itself.

 

Option D. Tracheostomy: Tracheostomy is not indicated in the acute management of tension pneumothorax. It is generally reserved for long-term airway management in cases of chronic conditions or when prolonged intubation is anticipated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate management of a tension pneumothorax involves needle decompression to rapidly relieve intrapleural pressure, followed by tube thoracostomy for definitive management. Proper identification and prompt intervention are crucial to prevent severe complications or death.

questions.text: Delphian lymph nodes belong to which level in neck nodes? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Level 6

 

The Delphian lymph node is a prelaryngeal lymph node located just above the thyroid isthmus. In the classification of neck lymph nodes, it is part of:

 

Also known as the central compartment, Level 6 includes the pretracheal, paratracheal, and prelaryngeal (Delphian) lymph nodes. This is the correct level for the Delphian lymph node.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Levels 3-4: These typically refer to the middle and lower jugular lymph nodes, which are located along the mid and lower third of the internal jugular vein.

 

Option B. Levels 1-2: Level 1 includes the submental and submandibular nodes, and Level 2 includes the upper jugular lymph nodes. These are not the locations of the Delphian lymph node.

 

Option C. Level 5: This includes the posterior triangle group of lymph nodes, located along the lower half of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, extending into the supraclavicular fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Delphian lymph node is categorized as Level 6 in the classification of neck lymph nodes, situated in the central compartment above the thyroid isthmus.

questions.text: A patient suffered burns following which the surgical procedure was done as shown in the image. Which of the following best describes the likely procedure done? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiersch skin graft

 

The image shows a meshed graft, which is characteristic of a Thiersch skin graft, also known as a split-thickness skin graft (STSG). This type of graft involves taking a thin layer of skin from a donor site, which includes the epidermis and part of the dermis. The meshing process creates perforations in the graft, increasing its surface area and allowing exudates to escape, which facilitates healing. Meshing also helps the graft to cover a larger area, which is particularly useful in cases of extensive burns.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Full thickness skin graft: This involves transplanting the entire thickness of the skin (epidermis and entire dermis). These grafts are typically used for areas requiring better cosmetic outcomes, such as the face, and are not usually meshed.

 

Option C. Biological mesh: This is used in various surgical repairs, such as hernias, and involves biological material to reinforce or replace tissue. It is not typically used for skin grafting in burns.

 

Option D. Artificial membrane: This refers to synthetic or biologically engineered membranes used to cover wounds or burns. The image shows a skin graft rather than an artificial membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A meshed appearance on a graft used for burn treatment indicates a Thiersch skin graft (split-thickness skin graft), which is designed to cover a larger area and facilitate exudate drainage.

questions.text: Identify the most important risk factor for acute mastitis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cracked nipple
 

The most important risk factor for acute mastitis is the presence of cracks and fissures in the nipples. These openings provide a direct entry point for bacteria, primarily Staphylococcus aureus, which commonly inhabits the oropharynx of the nursing infant. This condition often arises during the first month of breastfeeding when the nipples are most vulnerable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Massage: While massage can sometimes be recommended to alleviate symptoms of engorgement or blocked ducts, improper or overly vigorous massage is not a significant risk factor for developing acute mastitis.

 

Option B. Breast engorgement: Breast engorgement can lead to blocked ducts and potentially contribute to mastitis if milk is not effectively removed, but it is not the most important risk factor compared to cracked nipples.

 

Option C. Lactation failure: Lactation failure can cause issues such as milk stasis and engorgement, which might predispose to infection. However, it is not as direct a risk factor as cracked nipples, which provide a clear pathway for bacterial entry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of cracks and fissures in the nipples is the most important risk factor for acute mastitis due to the direct pathway it provides for bacterial entry.

choices.text: Direct inguinal hernia
Indirect inguinal hernia

questions.text: A patient presents with herniation of intestinal loop which passes along the spermatic cord and reaches till scrotum. Identify the pathology. (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Indirect inguinal hernia

 

An indirect inguinal hernia occurs when a hernia protrudes through the deep inguinal ring, travels through the inguinal canal along with the spermatic cord, and exits through the superficial inguinal ring. This type of hernia is more likely to descend into the scrotum, which aligns with the presentation described in the question.

 

  • Indirect Inguinal Hernia:
    • Pathway: Protrudes through the deep inguinal ring, travels along the inguinal canal with the spermatic cord, and can exit through the superficial inguinal ring.
    • Location: Lateral to the inferior epigastric artery.
    • Also Known As: Lateral hernia.
  • Boundaries of Hesselbach's Triangle (for Direct Inguinal Hernia):
    • Laterally: Inferior epigastric artery.
    • Medially: Lateral border of rectus abdominis muscle.
    • Inferiorly: Inguinal ligament.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Femoral hernia:
    • Occurs below the inguinal ligament through the femoral canal and typically presents as a bulge in the upper thigh or groin. It does not follow the pathway described and does not extend into the scrotum.
  • Option B. Direct inguinal hernia:
    • Occurs directly through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal within Hesselbach's triangle. It is typically medial to the inferior epigastric artery and does not usually descend into the scrotum.
  • Option D. Paraumbilical hernia:
    • Occurs near the umbilicus and involves herniation of the abdominal contents near the belly button. It does not follow the inguinal canal and does not extend into the scrotum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An indirect inguinal hernia is characterized by herniation through the deep inguinal ring, traveling along the inguinal canal with the spermatic cord, and potentially extending into the scrotum. This type of hernia is lateral to the inferior epigastric artery and distinct from other types of hernias based on its pathway and location.

questions.text: Which biopsy technique is used to diagnose Marjolin ulcer? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wedge biopsy

 

Wedge biopsy involves the removal of a small, wedge-shaped piece of tissue from the border of an ulcer. This technique is particularly useful in diagnosing Marjolin ulcers because it is the site where squamous cell carcinomas have maximum proliferation, leading to “everted edge”. Marjolin ulcers often develop in areas of previously injured or scarred skin, and a wedge biopsy can provide a representative sample for histopathological examination to confirm the presence of malignancy.


Other Options:

 

Option B. Excision biopsy: Excision biopsy is the technique of choice for a cervical lymph node pathology, in which the entire lymph node is surgically removed for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Core needle biopsy: Core needle biopsy is preferred for sampling soft tissue sarcomas, in which a small sample of tissue is removed using a large bore needle for examination.

 

Option D. USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC): USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is the technique of choice for a solitary thyroid nodule, in which a small amount of thyroid tissue is aspirated using a thin needle and examined under a microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A wedge biopsy is the preferred and commonly used biopsy technique to diagnose Marjolin ulcers because it allows for the examination of tissue from the ulceration site.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of revised trauma score (RTS)?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pulse rate

 

Pulse rate is NOT a part of revised trauma score.

 

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a scoring system used to evaluate the severity of traumatic injuries in patients.

 

It takes into account the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate to calculate a score that can predict the likelihood of survival.

 

The score range is 0-12.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glasgow Coma Scale: The GCS is included in the RTS and evaluates the patient's level of consciousness based on eye, verbal, and motor responses.

 

Option B. Systolic Blood Pressure: SBP is included in the RTS and measures the pressure in the arteries when the heart beats.

 

Option D. Respiratory Rate: RR is included in the RTS and measures the number of breaths per minute.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) includes the Glasgow Coma Scale, systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate, but does not include pulse rate.

questions.text: In a patient with thyroid malignancy, serum calcitonin was found to be elevated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer that arises from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid, which produce the hormone calcitonin. Elevated serum calcitonin is a characteristic marker for MTC. In addition to calcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) can also be elevated in MTC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular thyroid carcinoma: This is incorrect because follicular thyroid carcinoma typically does not elevate calcitonin. Instead, it may show elevated serum thyroglobulin.

 

Option B. Papillary thyroid carcinoma: This is incorrect because papillary thyroid carcinoma is associated with elevated serum thyroglobulin, not calcitonin.

 

Option D. Anaplastic carcinoma: This is incorrect as anaplastic carcinoma is an aggressive form of thyroid cancer that does not produce calcitonin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is the thyroid cancer associated with elevated serum calcitonin levels, distinguishing it from other types of thyroid malignancies.

choices.text: Posterior Urethral valves
Hydronephrosis to compare abdominal and urinary bladder pressures
Benign prostatic hyperplasia

questions.text: Whitaker test is performed for: (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydronephrosis to compare abdominal and urinary bladder pressures

 

The Whitaker test is a diagnostic procedure used to evaluate the severity of urinary tract obstruction, particularly at the pelviureteric junction (PUJ). This test is designed to compare pressures within the renal pelvis and the bladder to determine if there is a significant obstruction.

 

The procedure involves puncturing the kidney and infusing contrast percutaneously to measure the intrapelvic pressure. If the pressure rises significantly during the test, it indicates an obstruction at the PUJ, which can lead to hydronephrosis. Hydronephrosis is a condition characterized by the swelling of a kidney due to a build-up of urine, often caused by an obstruction in the urinary tract.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Posterior Urethral valves:
    • This condition involves obstructive membranes in the posterior male urethra, which can lead to urinary retention and damage to the kidneys and bladder. Diagnosis and treatment typically involve cystoscopy and valve ablation, not the Whitaker test.
  • Option C. Ureterocele:
    • A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the lower end of the ureter that can cause obstruction. Diagnosis is typically made via ultrasound, voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG), or intravenous pyelogram (IVP). The Whitaker test is not typically used for this condition.
  • Option D. Benign prostatic hyperplasia:
    • This condition involves the enlargement of the prostate gland, which can obstruct urine flow from the bladder. Diagnosis and management often include digital rectal examination, PSA testing, and imaging studies like ultrasound or cystoscopy. The Whitaker test is not used for evaluating benign prostatic hyperplasia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Whitaker test is a pressure flow study used to measure the pressure difference between the kidney and the bladder, specifically to evaluate the severity of obstruction in cases of hydronephrosis, particularly at the pelviureteric junction (PUJ).

questions.text: What TNM stage is appropriate for a woman with a breast lump and peau d'orange appearance affecting more than two-thirds of the breast?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T4d

 

Peau d'orange (orange peel appearance) is a clinical sign indicating skin involvement in breast cancer. The TNM staging system for breast cancer classifies tumors with peau d'orange under T4b. However, when the peau d'orange affects a significant portion of the breast, specifically more than one-third of the breast skin, it indicates a more advanced stage known as inflammatory breast carcinoma, which is classified as T4d.

 

Given the information that the peau d'orange affects more than two-thirds of the breast, the appropriate TNM stage is T4d, signifying inflammatory breast carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T4a: This is incorrect as T4a refers to the extension of the tumor to the chest wall.

 

Option B. T4b: This is incorrect as T4b includes peau d'orange but only when it involves less than one-third of the breast skin.

 

Option C. T4c: This is incorrect as T4c is a combination of T4a and T4b, indicating extension to the chest wall and skin involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peau d'orange affecting more than one-third of the breast skin is classified as T4d, indicating inflammatory breast carcinoma.

questions.text: The Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma in situ does not include:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hormone receptor staining

 

Hormone receptor status, which determines if the tumor cells have receptors for hormones like estrogen and progesterone, is not included in the VNPI. While hormone receptor status is crucial for managing invasive breast cancers, as it determines potential responses to hormone therapies like tamoxifen, it's not a component of the Van Nuys grading system for DCIS.

 

Staining for estrogen and progesterone receptors is not part of the Van Nuys system used for grading DCIS.

 

The Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) is a grading system that helps to stratify patients with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) based on several factors to determine the likelihood of recurrence and guide treatment decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age of the patient: The age of the patient is one of the factors in the Van Nuys Prognostic Index. Younger age (below 40) is associated with a higher risk of recurrence.

 

Option B. Size of the tumor: Tumor size is an essential factor in the Van Nuys grading system. Larger DCIS lesions (> 4cm) are associated with a higher risk of recurrence. Thus, the size can influence the treatment approach.

 

Option D. Presence of necrosis: In DCIS, the presence or absence of necrosis plays a role in determining the prognosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma in situ does not include Hormone receptor staining.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image, which developed after 3 days of catheterization. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fournier gangrene 

 

This is a serious bacterial infection characterized by necrotizing fasciitis affecting the perineal, genital, or perianal regions. It often presents with rapid onset, pain, swelling, and crepitus due to gas formation, and is associated with high morbidity and mortality rates. The infection can spread quickly, and early surgical intervention is critical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gas gangrene: Also known as clostridial myonecrosis, gas gangrene is caused by infection with Clostridium species and is characterized by sudden, severe pain, swelling, and production of gas, which can be palpable as crepitus

 

Option C. Wet gangrene: This form of gangrene arises when the blood flow to an area is lost, and a bacterial infection develops. It typically affects extremities and is associated with swelling, blistering, and a wet appearance due to pus.

 

Option D. Scrotal hematoma: This is a collection of blood within the scrotal sac but does not involve an infection. It may occur after trauma or surgery. While it can cause swelling and discoloration, it does not present with the same level of systemic illness seen in gangrenous conditions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fournier gangrene is a urological emergency that involves necrotizing fasciitis of the external genitalia and requires prompt surgical debridement along with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with complaints of pain in the calf muscles after walking for a certain distance. The pain is relieved by rest and reoccurs upon resuming walking. Based on Boyd’s classification, what is the most likely grade? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grade III

 

The patient's symptoms are indicative of intermittent claudication, which is pain in the muscles due to inadequate blood flow that occurs with exercise and is relieved with rest. 

 

Patient gets pain on walking, but it compelled to rest leading to relief of pain. This is the scenario in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade I: This usually refers to asymptomatic or mild claudication, where the patient has noticeable pain or discomfort in the muscles but can continue to walk and pain disappears.

 

Option B. Grade II: Patient gets pain on walking, but it is bearable and can continue to walk with a limp. 

 

Option D. Grade IV: This implies pain is at rest (not included in the original Boyde’s classification).

 

Given the description of the pain being relieved by rest and reoccurring upon walking, it suggests the patient's symptoms are more than just mild claudication but have not yet progressed to rest pain, which would indicate Grade III.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The patient's symptoms of calf pain upon walking that is relieved by rest is indicative of intermittent claudication, likely corresponding to Grade III of Boyde.

questions.text: Elderly male with a 3-week presents with history of trauma, with CT brain image as shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SDH (Subdural Hematoma)

 

The correct diagnosis is Subdural Hematoma (SDH). In elderly patients with a history of trauma, a sub-acute subdural hematoma often presents with symptoms that develop gradually over weeks due to slow venous bleeding. The CT scan shows a crescent-shaped (banana-shaped) hyperdense area, which is characteristic of a subdural hematoma. The chronic nature of the subdural hematoma is suggested by the time course (3 weeks’ post-trauma) and is more common in the elderly due to brain atrophy, which increases the risk of bridging vein tears leading to SDH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EDH (Epidural Hematoma): An epidural hematoma typically presents with a biconvex (lens-shaped) appearance on CT imaging, occurring between the skull and the dura mater. It is often associated with a more acute presentation following head trauma, usually involving arterial bleeding, and is less common in the elderly unless there is a direct skull fracture involving the middle meningeal artery.

 

Option C. SAH (Subarachnoid Hemorrhage): A subarachnoid hemorrhage presents as hyperdensity in the basal cisterns, sulci, or along the surface of the brain on CT. It is most commonly associated with ruptured aneurysms and would not present with a crescent or banana-shaped lesion as seen in the provided CT image.

 

Option D. Contusion: A contusion would show localized areas of bleeding or edema within the brain tissue itself, often with a mixed density appearance due to the presence of both hemorrhage and edema. Contusions do not have the crescent shape seen with SDH.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Chronic Subdural Hematoma (SDH) is often seen in elderly patients with a history of minor trauma, presenting weeks after the injury with symptoms such as headache, confusion, or neurological deficits. The characteristic CT finding is a crescent-shaped collection along the convexity of the brain, distinguishing it from other types of intracranial hemorrhages.

questions.text: Heller's operation is done for: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Achalasia cardia

 

Heller's operation, also known as Heller myotomy, is a surgical procedure designed to treat achalasia. During this procedure, the surgeon makes a series of cuts into the thickened muscle of the LES to allow it to relax and improve the passage of food into the stomach. So, Heller's operation is indeed done for achalasia cardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carcinoma esophagus: Carcinoma of the esophagus refers to cancer that starts in the esophagus. While surgeries are often performed for esophageal cancer, Heller's operation specifically is not one of them. Instead, procedures like esophagectomy (removal of all or part of the esophagus) are performed for esophageal cancer.

 

Option C. Esophageal stricture: An esophageal stricture is a narrowing of the esophagus, which can lead to difficulty swallowing. It can result from various causes, including acid reflux or injuries to the esophagus. Esophageal dilatation (stretching of the esophagus using dilators) is commonly done for esophageal strictures.

 

Option D. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is a condition in infants where the muscle at the junction between the stomach and the small intestine (the pylorus) becomes enlarged, leading to obstruction. The treatment for this condition is a surgery called pyloromyotomy, where the thickened muscle is split to relieve the obstruction.

 

In conclusion, among the given options, Heller's operation is specifically done for achalasia cardia (Option A).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heller's myotomy is a surgical procedure used to treat achalasia cardia by cutting the lower esophageal sphincter muscle to relieve obstruction and improve swallowing.

choices.text: Superficial from border with normal tissue

questions.text: A patient presents with a growth on the lip as shown. How is the biopsy taken? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superficial from border with normal tissue

 

In cases of ulcerative growths, such as squamous cell carcinoma of the lip, the biopsy is typically taken from the border of the ulcer where the tissue is actively proliferating. This method is known as a wedge or edge biopsy, where a small section from the edge of the ulcer and adjacent normal tissue is removed. This approach is preferred because the most diagnostically significant tissue lies at the proliferating margins of the ulcer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incisional: An incisional biopsy involves removing a piece of tissue from the core of the lesion. This technique is typically used for solid masses, such as breast lumps, where a core sample is required to assess the deeper tissue architecture. It is not appropriate for ulcerative lesions where the proliferative activity is at the edges.

 

Option B. Excisional: An excisional biopsy involves removing the entire lesion along with some surrounding normal tissue. While this is useful for small lesions where complete removal is feasible, it is not the standard initial approach for large or ulcerated lesions like those seen in aggressive lip cancers.

 

Option D. Deep biopsy: A deep biopsy targets deeper tissue layers, which may be necessary for certain internal masses but is not suitable for superficial ulcerative lesions like lip growths, where the pathology is best captured at the surface and edges.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For ulcerative lesions, particularly squamous cell carcinomas, a biopsy should be taken from the border or edge of the lesion, including some normal tissue, as this area contains the most diagnostically relevant proliferating cells.

questions.text: An elderly woman underwent surgical resection of her bowel, and after a few months, she presents with easy fatiguability and tiredness. Blood smear evaluation shows macrocytic anemia. Which of the following bowel resections is least likely to cause this condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenum

 

The clinical scenario indicates a diagnosis of macrocytic anemia due to vitamin B12 and/or folate deficiency. The resection of the duodenum is least likely to cause this condition. Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the terminal ileum, and intrinsic factor (IF) secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach is necessary for its absorption. Vitamin B12 is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia with a peripheral smear showing macro-ovalocytes and a hypersegmented neutrophil. In contrast, the jejunum is mainly used in folic acid absorption, and the stomach and ileum are involved in the absorption of vitamin B12.

 

While the duodenum contributes to overall nutrient absorption, vitamin B12 absorption is mainly absorbed in the ileum. So, resection of the duodenum alone might not as severely impact vitamin B12 absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jejunum: Resection of the jejunum can potentially lead to malabsorption of folic acid, as this is primarily absorbed in the jejunum or ileum.

 

Option C. Ileum: The ileum is a significant site for the absorption of vitamin B12 and is also involved in folic acid absorption. Resection of the ileum can severely disrupt the absorption of these nutrients, leading to macrocytic anemia.

 

Option D. Stomach: The stomach is the site for production of intrinsic factor, required for B12 absorption.

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department after he fell from a motorbike and injured his perineum. He gets an urge to micturate but is unable to urinate. On examination, blood was seen at the tip of the urethra, and swelling of the penis and scrotum was seen. What is the site of injury? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulbar urethra injury

 

  • Clinical Features: Swelling and bruising in the perineal area; difficulty passing urine; blood at the urethral meatus.
  • Treatment Plan: Surgical repair, which may involve primary anastomosis or placement of a suprapubic catheter, depending on the extent of the injury.

 

The presentation of being unable to urinate (urinary retention), the presence of blood at the urethral meatus (hematuria), and the swelling of the penis and scrotum are all indicative of a urethral injury, most likely at the bulbar segment given the described mechanism of injury.

 

The bulbar urethra is the most common site of injury in cases of straddle injuries or perineal trauma, such as the one described in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Membranous Urethra Rupture:

  • Clinical Features: inability to pass urine; blood at the urethral meatus, suprapubic bulge, floating prostate (Vermooten sign).
  • Treatment Plan: Suprapubic cystostomy.

 

Option C. Prostatic Urethra Injury:

  • Similar to membranous urethral rupture.

 

Option D. Urinary Bladder Rupture:

  • Clinical Features: Severe lower abdominal pain, distention, inability to pass urine, signs of shock (hypotension, rapid pulse). No blood is seen at urethral meatus.
  • Treatment Plan: Immediate surgical repair to close the bladder rupture, followed by drainage of urine, and addressing any associated injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulbar urethra injury is a common site of urethral trauma, particularly in cases of straddle injuries or perineal trauma. The key clinical features include difficulty in urination, blood at the urethral meatus, and swelling of the penis and scrotum. The treatment often involves surgical repair or placement of a suprapubic catheter.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with flame burns. On clinical evaluation, there were deep burns involving the left upper limb, the right upper limb, and the anterior aspect of the chest and abdomen. How much percentage of burns would it be classified as? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 36%

 

The Rule of Nines, also known as Wallace's rule, is used to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) affected by burns in adults. This method divides the body into sections, each accounting for approximately 9% (or multiples thereof) of the TBSA.

 

  • Left upper limb: Each upper limb is considered to account for 9% of the TBSA.
  • Right upper limb: Similarly, the right upper limb accounts for another 9%.
  • Anterior aspect of chest and abdomen: The anterior trunk, which includes the chest and abdomen, is considered to be 18% of the TBSA.

 

To calculate the total percentage of burns:

 

  • Left upper limb: 9%
  • Right upper limb: 9%
  • Anterior chest and abdomen: 18%

 

Adding these together: 9%+9%+18%=36%

 

Thus, the patient has burns covering 36% of their body surface area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The total body surface area (TBSA) involved is usually worked out by the Wallace Rule of Nines wherein each upper limb is 9% of TBSA, 9% each for the front and back of lower limb, 9% for the front and back of chest, 9% for the front and back of abdomen, the head and neck 9% and 1% for the perineum.

questions.text: A young male presented with slight dragging sensation in the scrotum. On examination a bag of worm feel was noted in the left side of scrotum. However, testes were normal. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left varicocele

 

A left varicocele is an enlargement of the veins within the loose bag of skin that holds the testicles (scrotum). It feels like a "bag of worms" and is often described as such during clinical examinations. It's typically benign and more commonly found on the left side. On standing, these veins fill up, leading to the characteristic feeling. The condition can cause a slight dragging sensation in the scrotum but does not affect the testes themselves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left hydrocele: A hydrocele is a fluid-filled sac surrounding a testicle that causes swelling in the scrotum. The fluid collection can be felt as a fluctuant mass in the scrotum. It doesn't give a "bag of worms" feel but more of a smooth swelling.

 

Option B. Inguinal hernia: This condition occurs when tissue, like part of the intestine, protrudes through a weak spot in the abdominal muscles. This protrusion can descend into the scrotum, leading to a noticeable bulge. Although it may cause a dragging sensation, the feel on examination would be different from the described "bag of worms".

 

Option C. Epididymo-orchiditis: This is inflammation of the testicle and epididymis, often due to an infection. It typically presents with pain, swelling, and redness of the affected testicle. On examination, the testis and epididymis would be tender and enlarged, but it wouldn't feel like a "bag of worms".

 

Educational Objective:

 

A varicocele is characterized by a "bag of worms" feel in the scrotum and is often found on the left side, causing a slight dragging sensation without affecting the testes.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after suffering a stab injury to the lower chest. On presentation, he had bradycardia and hypotension which did not improve despite IV fluid administration. Chest radiography showed clear lung fields. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E-FAST

 

Given the scenario described with the stab injury, bradycardia, hypotension, and clear lung fields on chest radiography, there's a concern for a potential cardiac injury and tamponade, and E-FAST would be the most rapid and effective tool to evaluate for these as well as other potential injuries.

 

E-FAST stands for Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma. It is an ultrasound examination that is performed on trauma patients in the emergency department to identify any life-threatening conditions that need to be addressed immediately. The components of E-FAST include:

 

  1. Subxiphoid view: This assesses for pericardial effusion (fluid around the heart) which could indicate a cardiac tamponade.
  2. Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ) view: This assesses for free fluid (which could indicate internal bleeding) in Morrison's pouch (the space between the liver and the right kidney).
  3. Left Upper Quadrant (LUQ) view: This assesses for free fluid in the splenorenal recess (the space between the spleen and the left kidney).
  4. Suprapubic view: This assesses for free fluid in the pelvis.
  5. Anterior Chest view: This is performed bilaterally to assess for pneumothorax (air in the pleural space that can cause lung collapse) or hemothorax (blood in the pleural space).

 

The "extended" in E-FAST refers to additional views which can be added depending on the patient's condition and the clinician's suspicion of injury. These may include views of the thoracic spine and the lung bases to look for signs of additional injury.

 

 

E-FAST: Given the patient's presentation with hypotension, this would be the most appropriate initial step to rapidly identify a life-threatening condition in an unstable patient, like cardiac tamponade, which can cause bradycardia and hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tube thoracostomy: Also known as a chest tube placement, it is used to treat pneumothorax or hemothorax by draining air or blood from the pleural space. However, in this patient, the chest radiography showed clear lung fields, suggesting that he does not have a significant hemothorax or pneumothorax.

 

Option C. CECT chest: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the chest can provide detailed images of the chest's anatomy and may identify injuries to the thoracic structures. However, in an acutely unstable trauma patient, a CT scan is not the best initial test due to the time it takes to perform and the need to transport the patient to the scanner.

 

Option D. CECT abdomen: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen can identify injuries to the abdominal organs. However it will be avoided in an unstable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E-FAST is a rapid ultrasound examination used in trauma patients to assess for life-threatening conditions such as cardiac tamponade, hemothorax, and pneumothorax. It is the most appropriate initial step for an unstable patient with a stab injury, bradycardia, and hypotension, given its ability to quickly provide critical information needed for immediate management.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a mobile, rubbery mass in her left breast. A histological image is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis for the given image? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibroadenoma 

 

The finding of mobile breast and the histological image showing a mixture of stromal and epithelial tissue, often described as having a 'staghorn’ appearance is seen in fibroadenoma.

 

This is a common benign tumor of the breast, usually presenting as a mobile, rubbery mass. Histologically, it shows a mixture of stromal and epithelial tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC): This is the most common type of breast cancer. Histologically, IDC typically shows abnormal, invasive glandular cells that originate from the ducts and invade surrounding breast tissue.

 

Option C. Phyllodes tumor: This is a rare breast tumor that can be benign or malignant. Histologically, it is similar to fibroadenoma but typically shows increased stromal cellularity and leaf-like projections. It is not mobile.

 

Option D. Lobular carcinoma in-situ (LCIS): LCIS is a non-invasive condition in which abnormal cells are found in the lobules of the breast. Histologically, it shows small, uniform cells that fill and expand the lobules.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fibroadenoma is the likely diagnosis of a mobile, rubbery breast mass in a young woman, characterized histologically by a benign proliferation of stromal and epithelial components.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest sign in Crohn's disease? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aphthous ulcers

 

These are shallow, round ulcers that are often seen in the mouth but can also occur in the small intestine and colon in Crohn's disease. They are the earliest sign of Crohn's disease and are often recurrent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cobblestone appearance: This is a characteristic finding in Crohn's disease and refers to the appearance of the mucosa with raised, rounded, and separated areas resembling cobblestones. This is caused by transmural inflammation and can be seen in the terminal ileum and colon.

 

Option B. Deep fissured ulcers: These are another feature of Crohn's disease that can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract. They are deep, often extend into the submucosa, and can lead to the formation of fistulas or abscesses.

 

Option C. Rose-thorn appearance: This term is sometimes used to describe the appearance of the mucosa in Crohn's disease, where there are linear ulcers that are surrounded by raised, edematous tissue. This pattern is more commonly seen in the colon.

 

Educational Objective:


Aphthous ulcers are the earliest sign of Crohn's disease, often appearing in the mouth and gastrointestinal tract before more severe lesions develop.

questions.text: A patient gets a surgical removal of foreign body from stomach. The foreign body is shown in the below given image. Whom should this patient be referred to? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychiatrist

 

The picture given above is of a trichobezoar, a mass composed of ingested hair, often associated with trichotillomania (compulsive hair pulling) and trichophagia (compulsive eating of hair). These conditions are psychiatric disorders that require proper mental health management. After the surgical removal of the trichobezoar, it is crucial to address the underlying behavioral issue to prevent recurrence. Therefore, referral to a psychiatrist is essential to manage and treat the underlying compulsion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pediatrician: While a pediatrician may be involved if the patient is a child, the primary issue in this case is a psychiatric disorder requiring specialized mental health treatment.

 

Option C. Cardiologist: A cardiologist specializes in heart-related conditions and is not relevant to the treatment of trichobezoars or underlying psychiatric conditions.

 

Option D. Dermatologist: Although dermatologists treat skin and hair conditions, the compulsive behavior leading to trichobezoar formation is psychiatric in nature, requiring intervention from a mental health professional rather than a dermatologist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After the surgical removal of a trichobezoar, patients should be referred to a psychiatrist to address underlying psychiatric conditions like trichotillomania and trichophagia to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain and discomfort for the past few months. The patient also reported experiencing weight loss and loss of appetite. On evaluation, a mass is palpable in the upper abdomen, and an endoscopy shows an ulcerated lesion in the stomach. A biopsy of the lesion is taken and sent for immunohistochemistry. The biopsy sample is found to be positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100. Based on these findings. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GIST

 

The clinical presentation and the biopsy results suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST). GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, and it typically arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal or the pacemaker cells of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria. GISTs are often associated with symptoms of mass effect, such as abdominal pain and discomfort, and can lead to weight loss and loss of appetite. The diagnosis of GIST is confirmed by immunohistochemistry, which typically shows positivity for KIT (CD117) detectable in Cajal cells. Other immunohistochemical markers such as LCA, cytokeratin, and S100 are negative. Treatment options for GIST may include surgery, radiation therapy, or targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma is a common type of cancer that can occur in various organs, including the stomach. However, the immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question (positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100) are not characteristic of adenocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Hodgkin’s lymphoma: Hodgkin's lymphoma is a type of lymphoma that typically presents with enlarged lymph nodes and is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. The immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question are not consistent with Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma is commonly associated with the epithelial lining of organs, and its diagnosis would typically involve positive staining for cytokeratin. The immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question (negative for cytokeratin) do not support the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GISTs are mesenchymal tumors that typically occur in the gastrointestinal tract. They often express CD117 (c-kit), a marker commonly associated with GIST. The negative staining for LCA (Leukocyte Common Antigen), cytokeratin, and S100 helps rule out other possibilities and supports the diagnosis of GIST.

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident was brought to the emergency by the family members. His CT scan was done which showed the following image. Which of the following can be given to this patient in this situation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin K

 

The CT scan image shows a subdural hematoma (SDH), which is a type of intracranial hemorrhage characterized by a crescent-shaped bleed along the brain's surface, often resulting from head trauma. In the case of traumatic intracranial hemorrhage, the primary concern is to stop the bleeding and manage intracranial pressure.

 

Vitamin K is an essential factor in the clotting cascade and is used to promote clotting and reduce bleeding. It is especially useful if the patient is suspected to be on anticoagulant therapy, as it helps counteract the effects of such medications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alteplase: Alteplase is a thrombolytic agent used to dissolve clots in ischemic stroke or myocardial infarction. Administering it in the context of a hemorrhagic stroke would worsen the bleeding.

 

Option B. Retiplase: Similar to alteplase, retiplase is another thrombolytic agent and is contraindicated in cases of hemorrhage due to its potential to exacerbate bleeding.

 

Option D. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that prevents clot formation. Giving heparin in a situation of intracranial hemorrhage would further inhibit clotting and worsen the bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the event of a traumatic intracranial hemorrhage, such as a subdural hematoma, Vitamin K is administered to promote blood clotting and reduce further bleeding, especially if the patient is on anticoagulant therapy.

questions.text: What is the next step in management for a patient with head trauma whose CT brain scan reveals an epidural hematoma (EDH) with mass effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) An immediate craniotomy

 

When a patient with head trauma has an epidural hematoma (EDH) with mass effect, which means significant compression, the next step in management should be an immediate craniotomy (surgical evacuation of the hematoma).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Observe: Observation is an option for small EDHs without mass effect, which is a rare scenario as EDHs typically result from arterial bleeding and cause significant compression.

 

Option C. IV fluids: IV fluids may be given for other purposes like hypovolemia due to bleeding but are not the appropriate management for this condition.

 

Option D. Ventriculo-peritoneal shunt: Ventriculo-peritoneal shunt is performed for the condition of hydrocephalus not in the case of an EDH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with head trauma and an epidural hematoma (EDH) causing mass effect (significant compression) on a CT brain scan, the next step in management is an immediate craniotomy (surgical evacuation of the hematoma) to decompress the brain.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presented with painless right scrotal swelling for 2 months. The left testis was normal. There were enlarged para-aortic nodes. USG showed right testicular mass. What will be the management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High inguinal orchiectomy

 

Explanation: 


This is a classic presentation of testicular tumor (likely seminoma) with para-aortic lymph node metastasis. High inguinal orchiectomy is the standard initial management. The procedure involves removing the entire testis with spermatic cord through an inguinal incision. This approach is crucial because:

 

  • It allows control of lymphatic and vascular supply at the deep inguinal ring
  • Prevents tumor spillage and local spread
  • Avoids breaching the scrotum which could lead to tumor seeding
  • Helps maintain proper oncological principles

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biopsy of scrotal mass - Incorrect

 

  • Biopsy or FNAC is contraindicated in testicular tumors as it may cause tumor spillage and upstaging
  • Can lead to scrotal violation and altered lymphatic drainage

 

Option C. Scrotal orchiectomy - Incorrect

 

  • Associated with high risk of local recurrence
  • Breaches scrotal skin which can lead to tumor seeding
  • Changes the lymphatic drainage pattern
  • Can cause upstaging of the tumor

 

Option D. Biopsy of lymph node - Incorrect

 

  • Not needed at initial diagnosis
  • Primary management is always removal of the testicular mass
  • Para-aortic nodes are consistent with the natural lymphatic spread pattern
  • Further staging can be done after orchiectomy

 

Educational Objective:
